page.title: 01PERSHORE
page.content: {GAZETTEER} Pershore derives its name from the Middle English{Perch_Ora}or Place of Osier Banks. It lies in the Avon Valley and its mill was recorded in the original{Domesday Book.}The terrain is predominantly gentle undulations and the valley is a fertile growing area for fruit and vegetables. Pershore egg plums are famed the world over. The town is dominated by the ancient{Abbey Church {of Holy Cross}with its lantern tower and the lesser church of{St Andrews.} It has a large wholesale market for local growers and is a pleasant stopping place for river long boat tourists. It has in{Bridge Street and Broad {Street}some of the finest examples of Georgian building in England.
